verses.text: So Israel set out with all that he had, and he came to Beersheba and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
verses.comment: Beersheba is repeatedly a place of encounter and covenant with God. Israel (Jacob) demonstrates reverence by offering sacrifices before leaving the land, reflecting trust in God's promises. See also ancestral worship patterns (Gen. 28:10–22).

verses.text: And God spoke to Israel in visions of the night and said, 'Jacob, Jacob.' And he said, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: God calling Jacob by name twice emphasizes intimacy and urgency. The vision continues the pattern of divine guidance to the patriarchs.

verses.text: And he said, 'I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for there I will make you into a great nation.'
verses.comment: God reassures Jacob of His providence and covenant faithfulness. The move to Egypt fulfills God's earlier prediction (Gen. 15:13-14), showing divine ordination of Israel’s history.

verses.text: 'I myself will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also bring you up again. And Joseph’s hand shall close your eyes.'
verses.comment: God’s personal presence is promised, foreshadowing both the Exodus and ultimate spiritual deliverance. Joseph’s hand closing Jacob’s eyes signifies filial piety and providential care at life’s end.

verses.text: Then Jacob set out from Beersheba. The sons of Israel carried Jacob their father, their little ones, and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s provision for Israel’s family highlights God’s use of earthly authority for the unfolding divine plan, showing synergy between natural and supernatural guidance.

verses.text: They took their livestock and the possessions they had acquired in the land of Canaan, and came into Egypt, Jacob and all his offspring with him.
verses.comment: This mirrors Abraham’s journey and marks the migration part of salvation history. The entire household moves, signifying unity and faithfulness to God’s promise.

verses.text: His sons and his grandsons, his daughters and his granddaughters, and all his offspring he brought with him into Egypt.
verses.comment: The text intentionally highlights the totality of the migration, foreshadowing the formation of God’s people as a nation.

verses.text: Now these are the names of the sons of Israel, Jacob and his sons, who went to Egypt: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn,
verses.comment: Genealogies root Israel’s identity in family and covenant lineage. The detail supports the reliability of Israel’s history.

verses.text: And the sons of Reuben: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
verses.comment: Names listed align with later tribal divisions, showing the continuity of sacred tradition. Cf. Num. 26.

verses.text: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
verses.comment: Poignantly notes intermarriage with Canaanites, a theme revisited regarding Israel's holy distinctiveness.

verses.text: The sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.comment: Descendants of Levi will later serve special priestly roles (Num. 3; Num. 8:6–22), reflected in sacred leadership and continuity.

verses.text: The sons of Judah: Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah (but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan). The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
verses.comment: Judah’s line is crucial for messianic expectation, as Jesus traces His lineage here (Matt. 1:2-3).

verses.text: The sons of Issachar: Tola, Puvah, Iob, and Shimron.
verses.comment: Tribal listings preserve sacred memory of God’s faithfulness, connecting each generation with the Promise.

verses.text: The sons of Zebulun: Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
verses.comment: Every tribe is named individually, showing both collective and personal aspects in salvation history.

verses.text: These were the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan-aram, together with his daughter Dinah. Altogether his sons and daughters numbered thirty-three.
verses.comment: Even female offspring are noted, reinforcing the inclusiveness of God’s covenant family. The number thirty-three indicates an exact record for sacred purposes.

verses.text: The sons of Gad: Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
verses.comment: Again, genealogical thoroughness underscores God’s order in assembling His people.

verses.text: The sons of Asher: Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, with Serah their sister. And the sons of Beriah: Heber and Malchiel.
verses.comment: Including Serah, a daughter, is unusual for these records, highlighting the value of women within the family and worship structure.

verses.text: These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah, and she bore these to Jacob—sixteen persons in all.
verses.comment: Zilpah, as a handmaid, signifies God’s work even through humble and overlooked members, affirming the dignity of each in God’s family.

verses.text: The sons of Rachel, Jacob’s wife: Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.comment: Rachel’s children maintain a unique role in Israel's history, especially Joseph’s future saving action, which prefigures later redeemer figures.

verses.text: And to Joseph in the land of Egypt were born Manasseh and Ephraim, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, bore to him.
verses.comment: Joseph’s sons are later adopted by Jacob as tribal heads, underscoring spiritual adoption as an ongoing biblical theme.

verses.text: The sons of Benjamin: Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
verses.comment: Ten sons for Benjamin, perhaps indicating God’s multiplying blessing even out of tragedy (see Gen. 35:18-19).

verses.text: These are the sons of Rachel, who were born to Jacob—fourteen persons in all.
verses.comment: The total solidifies Rachel’s honored place in Israel’s lineage.

verses.text: The sons of Dan: Hushim.
verses.comment: Dan’s line is singularly named, setting up later developments concerning the tribe.

verses.text: The sons of Naphtali: Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
verses.comment: Naphtali’s sons continue the pattern of detailed preservation of lineage.

verses.text: These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel, his daughter, and she bore these to Jacob—seven persons in all.
verses.comment: Bilhah, like Zilpah, demonstrates God’s inclusion of all, regardless of social status, in His gracious plan. Numbers symbolize completeness.

verses.text: All the persons who came with Jacob into Egypt, who were his direct descendants, not including the wives of Jacob’s sons, were sixty-six persons in all.
verses.comment: The number sixty-six is exclusive to direct descendants, reaffirming meticulous faithfulness in transmission of genealogical record.

verses.text: And the sons of Joseph, who were born to him in Egypt, were two. All the persons of the house of Jacob who came into Egypt were seventy.
verses.comment: Seventy is symbolic of fullness and completeness, often associated in biblical literature with the nations and the universal scope of God’s plan.

verses.text: He sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph, to lead the way before him to Goshen. And they came into the land of Goshen.
verses.comment: Judah's role as forerunner prefigures his tribe’s later leadership and messianic importance (see Gen. 49:10).

verses.text: Joseph made ready his chariot and went up to meet Israel his father in Goshen. He appeared before him, fell on his neck, and wept on his neck a long time.
verses.comment: The embrace testifies to deep familial love and forgiveness, echoing reunion themes that prefigure later biblical reconciliations.

verses.text: And Israel said to Joseph, 'Now let me die, since I have seen your face and know that you are still alive.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s words express contentment in God’s providence, reminiscent of Simeon’s prayer in Luke 2:29-30—a typological connection.

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s household, 'I will go up and tell Pharaoh, and will say to him, “My brothers and my father’s household, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.”'
verses.comment: Joseph’s action illustrates mediation between his family and Egyptian authority, a model of intercession that echoes forward to priestly and messianic work.

verses.text: 'And the men are shepherds, for they have been keepers of livestock, and they have brought their flocks and herds and all that they have.'
verses.comment: Shepherding distinguishes Israel from the Egyptians, symbolizing both literal and spiritual separation and vocation.

verses.text: 'When Pharaoh calls you and says, “What is your occupation?”'
verses.comment: Joseph prepares his family to state their calling, highlighting the importance of truth and identity.

verses.text: 'you shall say, “Your servants have been keepers of livestock from our youth even until now, both we and our fathers,” so that you may dwell in the land of Goshen; for every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians.'
verses.comment: God’s providence is seen as He arranges for Israel to maintain holiness and distinctiveness in Goshen, protecting their faith and tradition within a foreign land. This theme of separation and worship will develop throughout salvation history, paralleling later ecclesial realities where the faithful are called to live apart yet within the world.
